body:
```
api/private/helpers.h.generated.h:31:96: note: expected ‘unsigned int *’ but argument is of type ‘_Bool *’
   31 | DLLEXPORT int64_t normalize_index(buf_T *buf, int64_t index, unsigned end_exclusive, unsigned *oob);
```

gcc 15 hasn't been released yet. This looks like some header issue, either a bug in gcc or your system. We declare the function as `bool *oob`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/fe7be7ae95d7627fc7e0f0cb7d778803ba2424d7/src/nvim/api/private/helpers.c#L462

Or is our `src/nvim/generators/gen_declarations.lua` script generating the `unsigned *oob` declaration? When I open `build/include/api/private/helpers.h.generated.h` on my system, I see:

```c
DLLEXPORT int64_t normalize_index(buf_T *buf, int64_t index, _Bool end_exclusive, _Bool *oob);
```

What do you see?

rename.from: Neovim fails to build with GCC 15

body: I don't think it's a bug in GCC 15, but they switched to C23, which deprecated `_Bool` and introduced a real `bool` type.  So, the generated file should probably have the same signature and use `bool`

> When I open `build/include/api/private/helpers.h.generated.h` on my system, I see:
> 
> `DLLEXPORT int64_t normalize_index(buf_T *buf, int64_t index, _Bool end_exclusive, _Bool *oob);`
> 
> What do you see?

It's same as yours Justin (on a gcc <15 system)

> C23, which deprecated `_Bool` and introduced a real `bool`

Aha, that explains it.

I found this[0], according to which

> Several keywords in current C2x have weird spellings as reserved names that have ensured
> backwards compatibility for existing code bases. As a reply to a previous paper in this
> series, replacing the keywords

And _Bool is included in that keyword list.

[0]: https://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n2934.pdf

> is the gen_declarations.lua dependent on GCC version some how. I get slightly different helpers.h.generated.h files with GCC 14 and GCC 15.

yep, it reads some headers or macros from the system somewhere. Needs investigation to decide if our script needs a fix or if it's a gcc problem.

> Needs investigation to decide if our script needs a fix or if it's a gcc problem.

Looks like the latter -- https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=117633

I don't see `bool` treated as `unsigned` with gcc 15.0.1:

````
<mock-chroot> sh-5.2# gcc --version                                                                                                                                                       
gcc (GCC) 15.0.1 20250114 (Red Hat 15.0.1-0)                                                                                                                                              
Copyright (C) 2025 Free Software Foundation, Inc.                                                                                                                                         
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO                                                                                                                
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                          
<mock-chroot> sh-5.2# grep normalize_index include/api/private/helpers.h.generated.h                                                                                                      
DLLEXPORT int64_t normalize_index(buf_T *buf, int64_t index, _Bool end_exclusive, _Bool *oob);                                                                                            
<mock-chroot> sh-5.2#
```

It complains that bool != _Bool for me.
Ok, `gen_declarations.lua` uses as input `src/nvim/auto/api/private/helpers.i` which is the preprocessed `helpers.c`. So the preprocessor already generates the `_Bool`.
FYI: I've assigned https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2340915 to the gcc developers, I think it is a preprocessor bug.

issue.title: Fix building with GCC 15

labels.name: build
labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
This causes build failures with gcc 15.

Fixes #31723
